title: Aussies exploring own backyard
text:
What are these? Rising popularity ... Melbourne clawed back some marketshare from Sydney in the domestic travel arena in the last year. Picture: Supplied. Source: Supplied 
AUSTRALIANS are spending more time seeing their own country, with the latest snapshot of domestic tourism showing a healthy increase in visitor nights and spending in the year to March. 
The latest National Visitor Survey by Tourism Research Australia , revealed Aussies forked out $55.7 billion on domestic travel, up six per cent on the previous year, and spent 312 million nights away from home. 
The big winners from the revival of interest in homegrown travel were Tasmania, which recorded double digit growth, Victoria and Western Australia. Less thrilling ... The Gold Coast lost ground to the Sunshine Coast in the domestic travel arena. Picture: News Corp Australia Source: News Limited 
All states achieved year on year growth in spending and visitors but on a city by city basis, Sydney lost ground to Melbourne and the Gold Coast suffered a 5.6 per cent slump in domestic visitors, who headed to the Sunshine Coast instead. 
The downturn saw the Gold Coast tumble out of the top five most popular regions to visit, slipping to seventh behind Perth and the New South Wales’ South Coast. 
Despite its role as the G20 host in late 2014, Brisbane failed to see strong gains in visitors, but remained Australia’s third most popular destination behind Sydney and Melbourne. Popular ... Domestic travel to Melbourne gained momentum in the year to March. Picture: VicTourism. Source: Supplied 
The NSW North Coast held on to fourth place. 
Melbourne was the most expensive city to visit, with travellers spending an average $291 a night, ahead of Sydney ($261) and Perth ($251). 
Tourism Research Australia noted that the weaker Australian currency was likely to further boost domestic tourism as overseas holidays become more expensive. 
“In 2011, the Australian dollar was as high as US$1.11 and US$1.08 in 2012,” said a TRA spokesman. 
“The Australian dollar has average over US$0.96 cents since 2010. It’s currently at US$0.77 cents.” More to see ... Tasmania’s Great Eastern Drive. Picture: East Coast Regional Tourism Source: Supplied 
A number of states saw much of the domestic travel growth occur in regional areas including New South Wales, Queensland and Western Australia. 
Caravan and Camping Industry Association NSW CEO Lyndel Gray said that growth was most encouraging. 
“There’s so many towns across regional Australia where tourism is their lifeblood,” said Ms Grey. 
“It reflects what we’re seeing in terms of families wanting to show their kids how they holidayed as children, and wanting to take time together to explore their backyard.”
